I have pocket 8s on a K♠ A♠ 7♣ 7♦ board.  

On the flop I had the second-best pocket pair and an under-pair to any ace or king.  
 The turn 7♦ paired the board; now the board is KK A 77.  
With two 7s out there, the sets are now full houses, and either an A or K still beats my pair of 8s.  
My equity has gone down, and there are very few worse hands my opponent can have here; the obvious bluffs missed and hands like QJ, Q10 are behind.  
Stack-to-pot ratio (SPR) is about 24, so the pot is still tiny and I’m out of position.  
There’s no value in betting—only stronger hands (any ace, king, 7) will call or raise, and my pocket eights beat virtually nothing that calls.  
Therefore I check once more and plan to fold to future aggression, defending only if the price is extremely cheap (like free showdown).

Villain would have 3-bet pre-flop with pocket A-K/K-K/J-J+ often, and the turn raised smaller boats rather than just call 70.  
The natural value range for P1 is therefore a King with a weaker kicker (K-x, x < 5 is impossible since we hold K 5), or any pocket pair that made a two-pair on the flop/turn (9-9, 8-8, 7-7, etc.).  

The pot is 230 and stacks are 920 vs 850.  
I want to get maximum value from those worse hands while making it affordable for Villain to call.  
A bet of about 60 % pot (~140–150) seems ideal: big enough to extract, small enough to entice calls from weaker Kings and under-pairs.
